awd_titl_txt: DDRIG in DRMS: Rational and Heuristic Search
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores how people decide where to look when searching for valued outcomes (like products, services, or jobs) when many options are available. One example is how consumers visit travel websites when booking flights. This project helps explain the order in which a person would visit travel websites based on what they expect to find. In a series of online experiments, people are given choices like those they might face when shopping online, and their data about location search and choices are recorded. Participants’ behavior is summarized by describing the typical decision strategies that they use to make these decisions. These decision strategies are compared against optimal mathematical and economic models to identify inefficiencies and errors. Together the descriptive behavioral findings and the optimal analysis combine to make recommendations and innovations to improve online search. This research has the potential to enhance public understanding of online shopping and search behaviors. It can help government agencies, non-profit organizations, and corporations improve the design of their websites to help users find what they are looking for. It can also help consumers search for items online by highlighting common bad search habits that hinder effective searching. Finally, while this research focuses on consumer search, people search for many other things, jobs, opportunities, and services and the findings can be applied to these other situations as well.

This project explores how people navigate as they search sequentially for the best outcomes in an environment defined by search costs and differing expectations for outcomes at different locations. The goal of this research is to understand the strategies that people use to decide where to look for good outcomes based on search costs and their expectations (i.e., navigation). Studies compare observed strategies to normative economic models of navigation. This proposal is distinctive because it: (A) examines navigation behavior in the context of sequential search using controlled experiments; (B) compares navigation behaviors against the predictions of an influential optimal search model (Weitzman, 1979); (C) examines cognitive strategies used by people as they navigate in search; (D) develops a novel experimental method that allows comparing navigation behaviors to predictions from normative models and to identify simplifying heuristics; and (E) utilizes agent-based models to understand the adaptive nature of search heuristics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ability to search is an essential cognitive skill that underlies many human activities, from survival in primordial environments to finding good deals in modern economic markets. As the availability of information and tangible resources expands with the growth of electronic environments, search becomes ever more important for human achievements. Our research used laboratory-based experiments to explore the strategies and information that consumers use to navigate as they search for products.

To understand how consumers search, we developed a novel methodology which allowed participants to navigate while searching. In our experimental tasks, we manipulated the expectations that participants had about different locations that they could search. By doing this, we could infer how participants were using the information we provided them to make navigation decisions. We typically had consumers search in commercial settings. For example, in one of our studies, we had participants shop for a car. We presented participants with five car dealerships and told them that they should look for the car they liked best. They could test drive a car at as many of the dealerships as they wanted. For each dealership, we gave participants 50 user ratings for the cars sold at the dealership, and participants paid a small cost, representing the time and effort to test drive a car, to look at each brand. Once a participant looked at a brand, they were provided with a number that represented how much they liked the car after a test drive. The higher the number was, the higher the bonus that they received at the end of the experiment. 

Using this methodology, we ran a series of experiments that uncovered some of the thought processes driving human search behavior.  Overall, in simple search tasks, participants were roughly equally likely to navigate using one of two strategies. In one strategy, participants prioritized locations (e.g., the car dealerships in the example above) that had the highest average ratings. Other participants navigated based on the possibility of finding an unexpectedly good outcome, a strategy which is qualitatively like the best strategy possible in the types of searches we gave participants. When compared with the outcomes of the best possible strategy, participants did 95% as well. Importantly, however, participants using different search strategies often ended up purchasing different products. These results highlight the importance of understanding the different strategies that people use as they search. Understanding how and when people use these strategies can help governments develop better tools for guiding people as they search for jobs or services. Companies could use an understanding of these navigation strategies to attract different kinds of customers by accentuating information about their products and services.

We also looked at how complexity impacts navigation strategies. As people are faced with more information or information that is more difficult to comprehend, they need to adapt by changing their strategies. As we increased the complexity of our task, we found that participants increasingly relied on the layout of the display rather than the information provided about different locations. For example, when we increased complexity by adding additional locations, participants increasingly navigated from top to bottom. In a different study, we presented information in a circular display that made it hard to make comparisons between products when information about locations was presented graphically but not numerically. Participants were more likely to navigate clockwise when we made the comparisons more difficult. These results have important implications for the design of interfaces in electronic environments. They suggest that people looking for products in places with complex interfaces are more likely to be influenced by the layout of the interface itself and less likely to navigate based on the properties of the locations they are navigating to. These results suggest ways that designers of websites could improve user experiences and guide people to products or services that are most beneficial to their customers.

Overall, we find that people are good at navigating, even in complex situations. As they search, people skillfully use the information provided to them by the environment they are searching in to find what they are looking for without expending too much effort.
